brief_summary.textblock:
Emergency abdominal surgery is associated with high mortality rates, multiple postoperative
      complications and prolonged duration of hospital admission. The purpose of this study is to
      examine the postoperative functional performance in patients undergoing Emergency High-risk
      Abdominal Surgery. The hypothesis is that the study can describe the patient population in
      relation to postoperative functioning, degree of inactivity and the factors that limit
      mobility.

clinical_study.brief_title: Functional Performance Following Emergency High-risk Abdominal Surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients (19 years and older) undergoing emergency laparotomy or laparoscopy
             (inclusive reoperations after elective surgery).

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients undergoing minor emergency operations (uncomplicated appendectomy,
             laparoscopic cholecystectomy, diagnostic laparoscopy or laparotomy without
             intervention)

study_pop.textblock:
Patients (19 years and older) undergoing Emergency High-risk Abdominal Surgery at the
        Hvidovre University Hospital.

clinical_study.official_title: Functional Performance Following Emergency High-risk Abdominal Surgery

other_outcome.description: NMS is a measure of pre-hospital functional level.

oversight_info.authority: Denmark: The Research Ethics Committees of the Capital Region of Denmark

primary_outcome.description: Factors that limit independency in basic mobility will be evaluated on a daily basis.
primary_outcome.measure: Basic mobility evaluated by the Cumulated Ambulation Score (CAS)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Daily on postoperative day 1 to 7 and at discharge from the hospital (average length of stay is: 14 days).

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: VAS is a self-reported measure of pain intensity.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Daily on postoperative day 1 to 7 and at discharge from the hospital (average length of stay is: 14 days).

secondary_outcome.description: AMPS measures a person's performance capacity for activities of daily living (ADL) and/or independent living.
secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (AMPS)

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
